15.57.text:
I never knew my grandfather, because he died
at the age of 52, before I was born – he

21.97.text:
died in 1933, from I think leg wounds sustained
during the war – it was phlebitis and he

28.49.text:
died, I suspect, because of those wounds,
but he was a presence in the house, because

36.60.text:
my father was very proud of what he’d done.
He was my father’s father. And I know that

42.17.text:
he had a lot of photographs of his father,
both getting his medal, which was the military

52.35.text:
medal for bravery in the field, but also for
his singing ability. And there were quite

59.77.text:
a lot of photographs of him dressed up in
a fine dress suit or, I’m afraid, as a black

67.25.text:
and white minstrel, which he did in various
clubs around Lancashire. He was known as the

72.95.text:
Lancashire Nightingale. So, my grandfather
was a presence around – even though I never

83.20.text:
Yes, my grandfather enlisted, he volunteered
to enlist in 1916, and he went into action

93.30.text:
in 1917 at a hill, the hill of Loos, which
I understand was a terrible massacre really

103.03.text:
of people – I understand there are about
20000 unnamed soldiers who are buried there

110.51.text:
with just a memorial. So my grandfather was
on the hill of Loos on July 24th I think it

117.31.text:
was in 1917 and he was manning a gun – I
think it was a howitzer gun and he stuck to

128.14.text:
his gun for 8 hours – I believe all night
to try to repulse a German attack. Now he

134.94.text:
wasn’t, as far as I can make out, wounded
then – he was wounded, ironically, a month

140.03.text:
later in August and that’s when he was shipped
back to England with a terrible injury to

145.42.text:
his left leg and then he was in convalescence
for quite a while and then he was given a

152.67.text:
pension of 22 shillings a week and then went
back to his former job, which was as a waterman

161.20.text:
on the moors of Darwen but there would not
have been much money in the family, I suspect,

167.45.text: when he was invalided out of the army.

177.22.text:
My grandfather received the military medal
and he would have received the military cross,

183.97.text:
had he been an officer but he was a bombardier,
a private soldier, so he only got the lower

192.06.text:
order of the medal. I think he, from what my
father said, felt a little bit offended by that.

201.57.text:
My grandfather was presented with his military
medal in Darwen Town Hall when he came back

209.68.text:
from his injuries and he was presented with
his medal by the mayor of Darwen, and the

218.85.text:
mayor was very complimentary about him and
my grandfather was very stoic about the medal

225.48.text:
- and made some comment about not being in
favour of strikes – I think he said something

232.48.text:
like, ‘there are no strikes out there, my
friends’ – because he felt that people

237.94.text:
shouldn’t be striking at a time when the
country was under such strain and stress.

247.68.text:
The psychological impact, as I understand
it from my father, was quite dramatic. My

252.56.text:
father said that he went around in his nightmares
shooting Germans, and shouting out in his

260.31.text:
sleep – until he died. And there also quite
a lot of sad effects because the family had

269.04.text:
lost quite a lot of the possible income – my
grandfather always said to his children, there

276.97.text:
were three of them, ‘you will never go into
the mills, I will not let you go into the

282.32.text:
mills.’ And of course – they had to. They
all went into the mills at the age of 14 because

288.78.text:
there was not enough money to pay for their
education so although my father was apparently

292.44.text:
a very clever child, he never went on to higher
education – to secondary education. So there

299.31.text:
were all kinds of aftermaths of it, which
were, I think, very sad.
